body: I will be merging this PR by end of day. Please review and send in your comments before.

Interesting that the underscore character disappeared in my post and converted the MD to italics, but I think you understand my point.  It should be TRAFODION.<underscore>MD<underscore>.

I can merge it and add a comment. According to Rao, this is a "feature". We cannot detect duplicate rows in a batch at this point.

Ok, did the following: Added the JIRA, TRAFODION-1659 to the commit text. Also created a new JIRA, 1701, for the missing ability to handle batch inserts with duplicates. And also added a comment to the test, explaining why it does not check for the results right now.

Ryzuo, can you add the ORDER BY to the test in a future commit?

Sure thing. I'm running more tests to see how the rowsets are processed by sql, and I was planning update this with more test cases.
For now, seems with constraints violation within a batch, the whole batch will fail, while if there is just individual value invalid nothing related to any constraint, such as a string value is longer than the defined value of a column, the batch will insert successfully with just the individual row fails.
I will file JIRA for the issues I found, and commit another PR to update the test cases.

Listed all changes included in the latest code:
1. Remove snappy
2. Add permissions chmod 755 xxx
3.com.trafodion -> org.trafodion
4. Use "$MY_SQROOT/udr/lib" +user for base dir
5. Replace current_user with session_user 
6. For user name in path, replace '/' and '\' with '_'
7. Rename init_spj.sql to init_spj.sh
8. Rename schema name to _SPJ_  
9. Make changes on file name with CHARACTER SET UTF8
10. Rename the project name "spj_mgmt"
11. Link to top level Makefile
12. Remove CI_SERVER_LOG and rename sqlci path to bin64
13. Rename MANAGEABILITY_CATALOG  to CATALOG_NAME
14. Change echo messages echo"Creating Schema for CI Server Component

Looks good to me. Is this ready to commit?

Changes have been made to rewrite portions of the t4 driver code.  With
this delivery  all existing tests have been run and passed. This check-in,
however, disables several jdbc methods mostly related to T4 row sets. We do
not have regression tests for these jdbc methods. Therefore, if someone
writes a test to use one of the disabled methods a “not supported” error is
returned.  The tests that fail use scroll sensitive and scroll insensitive
requests.

I was hoping that this delivery would become the next release candidate and
it would be submitted to Apache.  However,  a decision needs to be made if
we should release this with missing functionality.  We are working on
adding these missing methods.

Since this is the first Apache release, no one has built using the source
tar file so there should not be any regressions.  Also people can still go
to the git repository and build from the release 2.0 branch that has this
functionality.  When release 1.3 is merged into 2.0, we will make sure all
the methods work as desired.

Opinion:

+1 – go ahead and release with unsupported methods

0 – no opinion

-1 – add code for unsupported methods

```
Roberta
```

Changes have been made to rewrite portions of the t4 driver code.  With
this delivery  all existing tests have been run and passed. This check-in,
however, disables several jdbc methods mostly related to T4 row sets. We do
not have regression tests for these jdbc methods. Therefore, if someone
writes a test to use one of the disabled methods a “not supported” error is
returned.  The tests that fail use scroll sensitive and scroll insensitive
requests.

I was hoping that this delivery would become the next release candidate and
it would be submitted to Apache.  However,  a decision needs to be made if
we should release this with missing functionality.  We are working on
adding these missing methods.

Since this is the first Apache release, no one has built using the source
tar file so there should not be any regressions.  Also people can still go
to the git repository and build from the release 2.0 branch that has this
functionality.  When release 1.3 is merged into 2.0, we will make sure all
the methods work as desired.

Opinion:

+1 – go ahead and release with unsupported methods

0 – no opinion

-1 – add code for unsupported methods

```
Roberta
```

Thanks for making all these changes, looks good!

Looking at Roberta's comments and at the naming and location of these SPJs, two more comments: We still have the question who should have execute rights for these SPJs. We do not want PUBLIC to have this right, since we are uploading code to the server. The other is naming: org.trafodion.mgmt is probably too generic, this is about UDR library management. IMHO, it would be good to put the code under core/sql/src/main/java/org/trafodion/udr/library_management. Roberta, could you propose the GRANT and possibly CREATE ROLE statements that we should use?
Is this fix is just temporary, until we put in the real fix in the binder? Do you want to use TRAFODION-1700 for the real fix or create a new one?
Thanks Amanda - I'll merge this change.

Hans, It is not clear to me if there is any other option other than select the row first. It it exists replace the omitted value with the value in the old row or populate with the default value for the column. This would make upsert to perform at the speed of scan. Do you think we should do this?
Also, this restriction is for the upsert command. It is ok to omit the column in case of insert.

Hi Selva, couldn't we handle this better? Upsert must be working by matching the clustering key of a new and existing row. If the row is new, then we insert default values for those columns that are not specified. If the row already exists, I would argue that we should overwrite the entire row, with the new one, choosing default values for those columns that the user didn't specify in the upsert. If users want something different they would have to use a merge statement. What do you think?

With regular hbase format, the omitted columns are never put into hbase either at the time of insert or upsert whether the row exists or not. The select substitutes the default value of the column if it is missing in hbase table.  So, this works well in regular hbase format when the upsert omits the column, the old value is returned with subsequent select or the default value when the column is missing. We can either put the default value or give an error whichever makes sense.with the aligned format for now. The aligned format table behavior will deviate from the regular hbase format unless aligned format is enhanced to omit the missing column in the row hdr info somehow. By giving out error, we let user to decide to use upsert into table with DEFAULT values or use merge statement in case of aligned format. However, I am also ok with silently substituting with default values when the row exists.
Yes, I am thinking of a fix in the binder that just adds all the missing columns, if the table uses aligned format.
It is currently being done in generator in addDefaultColumns in case of insert for regular hbase format and aligned format.Do you think it should be done in Binder only.
More changes expected. Please don't merge this change
Need to move this one along to the next step. Looks like some rework is needed here from what Steve suggests. Is it work in progress ?
